lesson_metadata.lesson_subtitle: Writing Equivalent Expressions Using the Distributive Property
lesson_metadata.lesson_description: In this lesson, students partition area models to see that the sum of the areas of the smaller regions equals the area of the whole model. They then rewrite the product of two factors as a factor times the sum of two or more terms, leading to the formalization of the Distributive Property.

feature_data.content: You know how to operate with numbers using different strategies. Taking apart numbers before you operate can highlight important information or make calculations easier.

feature_data.prompt_question: How can you use these strategies to express number sentences in different ways?

feature_data.introduction:
MLR 6: Three Reads

In Question 3 of Activity 1, Connecting Area Models and the Distributive Property, students use a given area model to explain the Distributive Property of Multiplication over Addition. This is an opportunity to implement Three Reads.
items: Have three different students read the definition of the Distributive Property of Multiplication over Addition aloud.
In Reading 1: Have students make sense of each variable within the definition as they relate to the area model.
In Reading 2: Have students explain the meaning of each side of the equation in the definition as they relate to the area model.
In Reading 3: Have a student read the definition and Question 3 aloud.
Have students work with a partner to answer Question 3.
Monitor students while they work to select a variety of explanations that students can share in a whole class discussion.

Use the Purposeful Questions to discuss what it means to distribute something, the formal definition of the Distributive Property of Multiplication over Addition, and the structure of the equation <math><mi>a</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>b</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>c</mi></math>.

feature_data.title: Assistance for All
feature_data.text:
Action & Expression: Expression & Communication

Students may draw a diagonal line to divide the area. While correct, discuss that their choice makes two trapezoids instead of rectangles, and it is much more efficient to use rectangles. Also, students will need to use rectangles to model the Distributive Property.

questions: Are students decomposing 27 into numbers that make the computation of the area more efficient?
Are students using the correct dimensions for each of the smaller regions in the area model?

feature_data.title: Challenge Opportunity
feature_data.text:
Engagement: Sustaining Effort & Persistence

Have students discuss what the equation looks like when they divide the model into more than two regions.

feature_data.content:
Developing Mathematical Language

Help students differentiate between the terms expression and equation. Have students share the similarities and differences between expressions and equations. Then, have them provide additional examples of each.

feature_data.title: Assistance for All
feature_data.text:
Representation: Building Knowledge

Demonstrate how the Distributive Property can help with mental math by expressing one factor as the sum of the tens and ones values. For example: 3 × 28 = 3(20 + 8) = 60 + 24 = 84.

feature_data.content: The context of a school gym provides an opportunity to connect to students' experiences and local community. Use this opportunity to facilitate discussions, such as what sports students like to play or watch, how they share the gym space during PE class, or whether they participate in any activities in community gyms in the local area.
